item.title: Nucleotide base
item.description:
About This Tutorial

Four different types of nitrogenous bases are found in DNA: adenine (A), thymine (T), cytosine (C), and guanine (G). In RNA, the thymine is replaced by uracil (U).

This educational resource provides a comprehensive overview of nitrogenous base structures, covering both purines (adenine, guanine) and pyrimidines (cytosine, thymine, uracil). Understanding these fundamental building blocks of DNA and RNA is crucial for students studying biochemistry and molecular biology.

Key Topics Covered

The tutorial explains the structural differences between purines and pyrimidines, their chemical properties, and their roles in nucleic acid formation. Ideal for medical students, university students, and intermediate-level learners seeking to master this foundational biochemistry concept.

Creator Information

Joy Prokash Debnath

  • SUST, Sylhet, Bangladesh
  • Department of Biochemistry and Molecular Biology (BMB), 1/1

Created: November 2020 (during the pandemic lockdown period) The chemical structures of A, G, C, T, and U are shown in this video.

item.title: Amino Acids
item.description:
About This Video Tutorial

This video tutorial presents a shortcut method to learn all 20 amino acids in just 10 minutes. Many students struggle with memorizing the 20 different amino acid names and their chemical structures, so this project aims to simplify the learning process through visual demonstration and mnemonic techniques.

Key Features

This resource is designed to help medical students, university students, and intermediate-level learners quickly understand and retain amino acid structures without the usual memorization burden.

Creator Information

Joy Prokash Debnath

SUST, Sylhet, Bangladesh Department of Biochemistry and Molecular Biology (BMB), 1/1

Date: June 30, 2020

Note

This tutorial includes visual explanations of amino acid structures. While efforts were made for accuracy, there are some minor technical notes regarding structural representations (such as tryptophan’s carbon bonds, arginine’s NH2+ bonding, and glycine’s alpha bond configurations).
